block.p: MIDTOWN Your Space or Mine: Sympathy for the Pedestrian

Public plazas and atriums have become fixtures in New York, spurred by zoning changes in 1961 that offered pedestrians breathing room as a tradeoff for taller towers. But questions have been raised as to their success. Most recently a study supported by the Municipal Art Society found that nearly half of the city's 503 public plazas and atriums did not comply with city rules.

The legacy of and impact of these privately owned public spaces is being examined in the Municipal Art Society's exhibition ''The World's Most Expensive Public Space.'' It features photographs, models, drawings and maps of 300 of these spaces. In addition, a series of public programs on the topic will include walking tours, a panel discussion and symposium, and a film screening.

FLUSHING MEADOWS A Borough's History, The Jazz Version

The Astoria Jazz Band is an offshoot of the Astoria Big Band, which was founded in 1986 by Carol Sudhalter, a baritone saxophonist. The 12-piece jazz band (pictured below) was formed out of the desire to perform big-band-style music at places that could not hold 16 musicians. The band has produced two recordings, ''Soon'' and ''Who Will Buy.''
This Saturday the jazz band will perform its original composition ''Queens: A Jazz History of the Borough Through the Music and Memories of Leonard Gaskin, Bassist.''

The concert presents the history through narration by Mr. Gaskin, a bassist and 30-year resident of the borough. He has performed with Louis Armstrong's All Stars and jazz greats like Dizzy Gillespie and Dexter Gordon.

The Astoria Jazz Band; Saturday 2:30 p.m.; Queens Museum of Art, New York City Building in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park; suggested donation: $3, students and people over 65, $1.50, members and children under 5, free; (718) 592-9700.
CENTRAL PARK Bang the Drum Gladly, In Celebration of the Spirit

Visitors can drum, sing and dance on Saturday at the New York Drumming Circle's Second Annual Shamanic Circle Gathering. For the last three years, members of the Drumming Circle have been studying with teachers known as shamans from the Amazon and the high Andes of Ecuador and Peru.

Saturday's event is a celebration of the spirit world, and the public is invited to take a rattle or a drum, or a notepad and a pencil, or a bandanna and a blanket. Picnics are encouraged but alcohol is prohibited.

Don Jose Juaquin Pineda, an Ecuadorian Yachek (Birdman shaman) who works with the New York circle, is shown below wearing his ceremonial headdress at last year's event. The group holds monthly events to teach the shamanic path.
Shamanic Circle Gathering; Saturday 1 p.m., until sunset; the Great Hill in Central Park, between West 103rd and 106th Streets; free; (212) 533-0909.

WORKSHOP -- Youngsters can prepare early for Halloween by making an owl mask today and their own castle cap on Saturday in the Staten Island Children's Museum walk-in workshops, 1 to 4 p.m; 1000 Richmond Terrace, near Snug Harbor Road; $2 plus museum admission: $4; children under 2 and museum members free; (718) 273-2060.

PATRIOT IN FACT AND FICTION -- The recent film ''The Patriot'' will be one topic of a discussion on ''Dramatizing the American Revolution: The Patriot, Myth and Reality''; panelists include Thomas Fleming, the novelist, and John Buchanan, a military historian; today 2 p.m.; New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street; suggested donation: $5; students and people over 65, $3; (212) 873-3400.

EMERGING ARTISTS' SHOW -- The Brooklyn Working Artists Coalition holds its Fall Small Works Show to give artists a chance to show works in a Red Hook warehouse provided by Greg O'Connell, a local developer; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 p.m., Saturday through Dec. 10; Bay One, 141 Beard Street, (Van Brunt Street); free; (718) 596-2507.
